Worst Case Scenario
#1 (Chlorine)
Worst case scenario is identified as a catastrophic failure of a cylinder containing 2,000 pounds of chlorine. It is assumed that entire contents would be lost over a span of ten minutes. The potential threat zone identified is 25 ppm at 3.0 miles. Affected housing units are 2,993 Total affected population is 13,748.
#2 (Methyltrichlorosilane) 
Alternative case scenario is identified as a catastrophic failure of a cylinder containing 2,200 pounds of methyltrichlorosilane. It is assumed that entire contents would be lost over a span of ten minutes. The 
potential threat zone identified is 25 ppm at 1.0 miles. Affected housing units are 243. Total affected population is 977.

Alternative Case Scenario(s) 
#1 (Chlorine - With Administrative Controls)
Alternative case scenario is identified as a release of chlorine transfer systems with a rate of 5 lbs per minute. The potential threat zone identified is 25 ppm at 0.1 miles. Affected housing units is 100. Total affected population is 200.
#2 (Methyltrichlorosilane - with Administrative Controls)
Alternative case scenario is identified as a release of methyltrichlorosilane transfer systems with a rate of 5 lbs per minute. The potential threat zone identified is 25 ppm at 0.2 miles. Affected housing units is 250. Total affected population is 500.

1.4 The General Accidental Release Prevention Program and the Chemical-Specific Prevention Steps:
SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys has implemented programs and procedures to comply with OSHA's Process Safety Management (PSM) requirements set out under 29 CFR §1910.119, and EPA's Risk Management Plan regulation 40 CFR §68. The following sections briefly describe the elements of the release prevention program in place.
a. Process Safety Information:
SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys maintains safety information that describes the chemical hazards, operating parameters and equipment designs associated with all processes. Information inclu

curring. All reports of incidents will be retained for a minimum of 5 years.
h. Employee Participation:
Employees are included in programs, procedures, and PHA's and is provided access to all reports, recommendations, and all other information required to be developed under this standard. Additionally, employees are actively involved in the conduct and development of Process Hazard Analysis and on the development of the other elements of Process Safety Management.

2. Five-year Accident History:
SGL has not had any release incidents that exceeded the reportable quantities identified by Risk Management Plan.

3. Emergency Planning:
SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys maintains a written Emergency Response Plan (EHSA-PRO-003 Emergency Action Plan) to identify, prevent, and respond to accidental/unauthorized releases of hazardous materials. This 
plan assigns responsibility for emergency management in the event of release, notifications, and use of emergency equipment as outlined in training programs. An emergency drill exercise is conducted at least 
annually to test elements of the emergency plan. The emergency response plan is reviewed periodically and updated as needed.

4. Planned Changes to Improve Safety:
SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys, is committed to continuous improvement of its people, processes, and products as an approved Responsible Care site. Routine audits are conducted at the site, and recommendations are 
implemented.

5. Certification Statement:
The undersigned certifies that to the best of my knowledge, information, and belief, the information submitted is true, accurate and complete.

management of change, emergency response plan, communications & alarm systems, notifications, evacuation, emergency assembly areas, headcounting, decontamination, PPE, personal protective equipment, use of emergency equipment, control and containment, hazard communication program, methods for safe handling of hazardous substances, incident reporting, process safety information, on-the-job skills training and verification, and review of applicable laws and regulations.
e. Mechanical Integrity:
SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys has implemented a written mechanical integrity program. A master equipment list has been developed with preventive maintenance procedures for each type of equipment. Preventive maintenance work orders are provided for routine maintenance checks of process equipment to ensure equipment is maintained in good condition. Process equipment in this program include but is not limited to: vessels, piping, valves, hoses, monitors, sensors, compressors, systems, and a weigh scale. Any equipment deficiencies identified during preventive maintenance checks are corrected in a safe and timely manner.
f. Compliance Audits:
Compliance audits at SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys are scheduled and conducted by SGL's corporate process safety and EHSS department at least every 3 years. Recommendations and opportunities identified during the audit are assigned responsibility and completed within the assigned time. Recommendations noted during any other audit performed at the site is also resolved in a timely manner. 
g. Incident Investigation:
SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys has demonstrated an excellent record of preventing accidental releases during the last 5 years, with no off-site release incidents reported. SGL investigates any incident that has, or could reasonably have resulted in an unauthorized release of a regulated substance. Investigations are used to identify the causes leading up to the incident as well as identify corrective actions to prevent release from reoc

des but is not limited to; standard operating procedures, SDS/MSDS, P&ID's, process safety procedures, mechanical integrity, and emergency response.
b. Process Hazard Analysis:
SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys has conducted a Process Hazard Analysis to ensure that hazards associated with the process are identified and controlled. Process Hazard Analysis' may identify opportunities for improvement that prevent or minimize potential releases. PHA studies are re-validated every five years or whenever changes in the process would affect process safety information. Recommendations and/or findings from a Process Hazard Analysis will be resolved by plant management in a timely manner. 
c. Operating Procedures:
SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys has implemented written standard operating procedures for purpose of safely conducting and controlling activities within the covered processes. Procedure elements include:  process description, block flow diagram, safety systems and their functions, raw materials, safety and health considerations, initial startup, normal operations, temporary operations, operating limits, normal shutdown, emergency shutdown, emergency operations, startup following a turnaround or after an emergency, chemical transfer operations, and sampling. SOP information is reviewed and is readily accessible to operators involved in the processes.
d. Training:
SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys has a training program in place to ensure that employees who are operating the system process are competent in the operating procedures associated with the process. Training program requires training and certification for new employees upon initial assignment and transferred employees before performing work . Recurring training is conducted annually, and certification is required at least every three years. Training program elements related to RMP include but are not limited to: Review of SDS/MSDS, standard operating procedures, emergency/safety systems, process safety procedures manual,

SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys, is committed to implement programs and plans that identify and reduce risk to help ensure the health and safety of its employees, environment, neighbors, and surrounding community. This 
commitment is demonstrated by implementation of its process safety and risk management programs. 

1.1 Accidental Release Prevention and Emergency Response Plans:
Policies and procedures have been developed to address accidental release and emergency response.  Management procedures and practices in place to maintain operational control at site include but are not limited to operating procedures, equipment maintenance and reliability, process hazard analysis, emergency response plan, management of change, pre-startup safety review, and employee training. It is the policy of SGL Carbon, LLC - St Marys to implement and maintain appropriate controls that meet and /or exceed all regulatory guidelines.

1.2 The Stationary Source and Regulated Substances:
Chemical substance(s) located at this facility that are subject to 40 cfr 68 112(r) regulations is Methyltrichlorosilane and Chlorine. Site's primary activity and function is to transfer, store and distribute various chemicals used in purification and coating of synthetic graphite. Methyltrichlorosilane and Chlorine are received into the facility via cylinder, and then connected to piping systems. This process is subject to process safety and risk management plans at the site.

1.3 Release Scenario(s):
A series of release scenarios have been modeled based on the type containers located on site. Worst case release scenario(s) and the alternative release scenario(s) have been modeled without inclusion of administrative controls and mitigation measures that would normally be present to limit dispersion distances for each reported scenario.
